Expectation1: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation1: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I was packing up my tools after a long day when my phone buzzed. A homeowner’s voice, tight with worry, told me their deck was splintered and unsafe. They needed it fixed today—guests were coming tomorrow, and the deck was the centerpiece. I promised I’d be there soon, knowing how much people rely on me to keep their homes safe and welcoming. As I loaded my truck, I glanced at the clock. Only a couple of hours left before the polls closed. I’d meant to vote earlier, but the day’s jobs had run long, and now I was squeezed between my duty as a craftsman and my responsibility as a citizen. The deck would take time—maybe all the time I had left before the polling station shut its doors. My mind raced with the weight of both roles: the trust the homeowner placed in me, the civic duty I owed my community. I gripped the steering wheel, torn, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
